repnme.cdata!: Sri Lanka - Third Industrial Development Project

abstracts.cdata!:
The outcome of the Third Industrial
            Development Project for Sri Lanka was satisfactory. The
            project achieved its objectives, its impact on institutional
            development has been significant, sustainability is likely,
            and the performance of both the Bank and Borrower was
            satisfactory. Several lessons can be learned from this
            project. First, the sustainability of the financial
            intermediary operations is a function of several factors.
            They are: a) financial viability of the credit institutions
            and their efficient loan administration; b) satisfactory
            implementation of the supporting TA programs; and c)
            satisfactory rate of return of the sub-projects. Second, the
            absence of an effective and proper system for monitoring and
            recording of the TA programs and lack of coordination
            between the TA recipients and the government implementing
            authorities contributed to the poor utilization, lack of
            sustainability, and low impact of TA in certain areas.
            Finally, the design and scope of the TA is also critical to
            achieving project objectives. For TA to be effective, design
            and objectives should be more specific and targeted.

repnme.cdata!:
Sri Lanka - Third Industrial Development
            Project (IDP III)

abstracts.cdata!:
The aim of the Third Industrial
            Development Project is for the creation of new and the
            balancing, modernizing and rehabilitation (BMR) of private
            industrial enterprises, and supporting the implementation of
            Government policy reforms and institutional strengthening.
            These objectives will be realized through : (1) mobilizing
            finance for new investment and BMR of economically viable
            enterprises; (2) technical assistance and training in the
            areas of industry, trade, and finance relating to the
            private sector; and (3) financing of technical assistance to
            the National Telecommunications Commission (NTC) to
            establish a regulatory framework for operations of a
            commercially run communications utility and private
            telecommunications companies.
